None
text:
This dip was a big hit. My husband took it to work and THEY DEVOURED IT! It was gone before it got cold. First of all, the recipe says to "spread" the ingredients into the baking dish. VERY IMPORTANT: Mix them well in a bowl first, then spread them into the baking dish. This is not a layered dish. It will not look "presentable" if there are chunks of ingredients all over the place. I used real roasted garlic. It isn't really a big step, and it does make a difference. You won't have difficulty peeling the soft garlic if you pound on the clove with the side of a wide knife. It comes right out. I also followed other suggestions and used a whole package of cream cheese. I used Bertolli alfredo sauce & it doesn't have a metallic flavor like other store bought sauces can have. Next time I make it, I'll keep it warm in my electric crock pot (If it lasts that long).

Edited to add: 
I made little filo dough cups in a mini muffin tin. I filled them with this dip that I heated in the microwave. I topped them with shredded asiago & romano cheese and melted it in the oven for about 4 min. I topped them with chopped tomatoes & they were a real HIT!
For the filo dough cups:
Layer 3 sheets of filo dough with cooking spray between each layer. Cut into, 18 squares. Put each square into mini muffin tins and bake for 5-7 min at 350.

text:
I've been making this recipe for several years, it's great! I use garlic powder (1 tsp) and usually leave out the artichokes and just use spinach. I use a 15 oz jar of alfredo sauce, 2 cups of mozzerella, about 1/2 cup Parmesan, and an entire 8 oz. pkg of cream cheese. I don't layer the ingredients, just stir everything together, pour in a casserole and bake till bubbly. I serve it with slices of hot, crunchy garlic toast. Fantastic!

This is absoultely DELICIOUS.  I serve it with pita triangles.  I've made it about 6 times since I got the recipe a few months ago, and each time my guests all agree that it's better than what you get in the restaurants.  I go ahead and use the whole cream cheese package just to make it easier.  I also mix up all the cheeses to make it easier to put in the pan, and I heat the cream cheese a bit in the microwave to soften and make it easier to mix.  Yummm!!!!

text:
EXCELLENT DIP!!!  I tried an artichoke spinach dip recipe once before and my husband told me that I should never touch an artichoke again :).   I tried this recipe and his eyes literally lit up!  This recipe was so easy to make, that I couldn't believe it.  I used store bought garlic that was already chopped and also added a little extra salt.  (I eliminated the need to bake garlic first and just mixed the garlic in with all the other ingredients).  It truly tasted like an Applebee's dip....or even better.  My entire prep. time was approx. 5 minutes.  The suggested cook time was absolutely perfect.  My husband asked me to make this recipe for the next food day at his job!!!!  This is truly a 5 star recipe.

text:
AWESOME IS AN UNDERSTATMENT!!!!!!!!!!
I have made this many times and after a few modifications Ive found perfect recipe. FRESH GARLIC is a must dont use minced this is what makes it so flavorful the extra time is worth it. I use the entire package of cream cheese and an entire bottle of Alfredo 15 oz. Mix everything very well to get the best blend. Finding the right cooking time was tricky I cook about 15 minutes longer but pull out and check often to find your favorite consistency. I actually like this recipe better the second day its SUPER YUMMY best recipe I have ever gotten online.

text:
Oh, this was great! I made it for christmas eve appetizers and my husband and I practically ate the whole thing in one sitting.
The only thing I would change is I would not get the marinated artickoes again. They were too salty and I would also chop them up. I didn't care too much for the big chunks of artickokes.
I also took some of the others advice and mixed all the cheeses and the sauce together and used the whole thing of cream chesse. I also added some pepper and garlic to the cheese mixture. Then I put mozzerella on top. For the cheese mixture I used an italian mix of cheese. 
Also, next time I make it I will mix everything together. I like it that way. 
thanks for a great recipe

text:
I've made this recipe twice.  With and without artichokes. -- better with them.  I used 2 tsp prepackaged chopped garlic and 1 to 1&1/2 tsp garlic powder instead of roasting fresh garlic cloves, and added black pepper. (Don't add salt, it's salty enough without)  I mixed everything together instead of layering.  Be sure to use fresh parmesan, not the powdery kind, and add extra in the mixture with extra mozz. cheese!! mmmm... cheese...  Per other reviews, I was scared to use jarred sauce, but couldn't find canned. Used Ragu's jarred alfredo sauce anyway (10 oz = 1&1/4 cup), and it was perfect.  Serve with chips, and great as leftovers too!

text:
HELPFUL TIPS WHEN SERVING TO GUESTS: I make this so much but each time end up having to re-read the changes I made b/c they COMPLETELY make a difference.  The biggest thing I've learned from making this so many times is... to invest in one of those warmers/small crockpot and letting this sit in here for guests.  It's so heavenly warm ...completely ick cold (but perfect if warmed up again).  Use the entire 8 oz cream cheese, never use Kraft Alfredo (for ANY recipe... not matter of taste..it just completely stinks and is watery) ...use the entire 15 oz alfredo if that's how much your jar is, and definitely up the mozz to 1.5 Cups.  Someone recommended 2 Cups and each time... it's too cheesy to my guests.  Don't get scared off by those who say you have to do the garlic step.  Do it ...don't. ....don't even add garlic... it will still taste fantastic!!!  I've done it the long way, the kind in a jar, and the powder.  All taste good. This is just the go-to when I have guests because they can't stop talking about it.  This is to DIE FOR!!

text:
Update: I just made this again for a Halloween get together and it is still fabulous and I never have leftovers.

I made this for a New Year's party and it was a hit!!!  I was a little worried after reading the reviews that the alfredo might be too prominent so I made a few adjustments.  I made a double batch and used a 16oz jar of alfredo, 1/4c fat free plain yogurt, 1/4c low fat mayo, 1/4c more of mozzarella and 1/4c more of parmesian. I also just used minced roasted garlic. I didn't read the directions properly and I mixed everything together - which is the way to go.  I then cooked it on low in my slow cooker so it could be kept warm all night.  It tasted better than any restaurant dip I have ever had AND it passed my picky husband test - he raved about it.  I will definately make this recipe again!

text:
This is excellent!  I made a few changes that make it a bit tastier and more simple.  I use Bertolli Garlic Alfredo sauce (jarred), whipped garlic & herb cream cheese, 1 Tablespoon minced garlic (jarred), 1/2 cup mozzerela cheese, 1 cup italian blend cheese, and 1/2 cup colby. I also chop the artichokes and add a little garlic powder and salt. I also mix all the ingredients in a bowl and top with a little shredded italian blend for presentation. This is not exactly a healthy choice, but a good "once-in-a-while" indulgence! I never have to worry about bringing home leftovers when I take it to a party--always a hit!

Holy moly!  This is the best spinach dip I have eaten or made.  I used 8 oz cream cheese, and a jar of alfredo, which was more than 10 oz, and 1 t garlic powder.  I softened the cream cheese in the microwave, mixed all in a bowl, moved to shallow dish and baked for 25 min.  OMG is all I can say.

text:
Updated 1/27/11:  I still make this all the time, but I've made it even easier because I don't bake it anymore.  I just mix all the ingredients in a casserole dish and microwave it until it's hot.  Everything melts together quickly and it tastes just like it's been in the oven, but takes a fraction of the time.  Original Review 3/19/02:  This dip was incredible and was so unbelievably easy!  I made this for a bridal shower and everyone wanted the recipe.  The bride's aunt wanted to take the leftovers home with her but I was selfish and kept them for myself.:)  I used fresh spinach that I steamed and finely chopped.  I just layered everything in the pan the night before, covered in plastic wrap and stored in the fridge until I needed to cook it.  I popped it in the oven and added about 15 minutes to the cook time (because it was cold) and it came out perfectly!  We served it in a hollowed out bread bowl and it was great!  The only change I will make in the future is to add more garlic (but we like garlic in my family).  I will be making more of this for myself!  Thanks for the great recipe, Terra!

text:
Absolutely delicious dip recipe and very easy to make (hardest part is baking and peeling the garlic and there's really not much to that).   Made exactly as the recipe called and wouldn't change a thing.  It was delicious - probably better than what I've had in restaurants.    It did take longer than 30 minutes to get "bubbly" - closer to 40 maybe 45 minutes in the oven.   Took out and transferred to a crock pot on warm for people to snack on throughout the day at Easter.   Very important to remove excess water from the spinach and artichokes before cooking.  Will definitely make again.

text:
Changes I made - which were very few.  I did not bake this.  I instead put it in my crockpot.  Used Bertolli alfredo pasta sauce.  Used a generic brand of frozen chopped spinach. Dont use marinated artichokes.  Drained and rinsed the artichokes very well (chopping them with a slap/chop type thing).  Used the Costco/Kirkland minced garlic, about 2 TBS.  Used a generic 2cup package cheese blend, mozzerella/parmesan.  Used the whole 8oz package of cream cheese.  I mixed everything together the night before in the crock and let it sit in the fridge until this morning.  High for 1hr, switching down to low for another 3hrs.  Giving it a good stir every 30 minutes or so.  Brought it in for a surprise baby shower and everyone raved about it! And I'm going home with a clean crockpot!  :)

text:
Although not a HUGE fan of spinach and artichoke dip, my husband is, so I made this for him.  I used the Quick and Easy Alfredo Sauce recipe from this site instead of buying it.  The whole thing turned out FABULOUS!  He swears it is the best dip he has ever had!  I really liked it too!  He loved the fact that it didn't have a layer of oily fat on the top like so many places serve - and he believes it is because I used the alfredo sauce instead of mayo.  I don't know about that, all I know is that it is a hit and I wouldn't change a THING!

Display Name:
What's Cookin'

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/755940.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this dip for my sister's baby shower yesterday and it was very good. I used half the spinach called for which was plenty and Trader Joe's Alfredo. I will try it with Bertoli Alfredo next time as several other reviewers stated good results with that. The dip had a great texture and consistency. UPDATE: I have made this recipe twice more since my first review and have gotten rave reviews from my guests both times. I now use the Roasted Garlic Bertoli Alfredo. I roast 5 garlic cloves drizzled with olive oil in my oven on 350 for 30 minutes, than mince those and add them to the mixture. To prepare I blend all my cheeses first. I lightly pulse the artichoke w/ 8 to 10 marinated sun dried tomatoes in the Food Processor taking care to get small chunks, not a paste. I stir the artichoke and cheese mixtures together and add about 2 handfuls of torn, fresh baby spinach omitting the frozen spinach all together. I stir to incorporate the spinach well and spoon it into a prepared, glass 8x8 dish. I add additional shredded Parm. to the top and bake as directed. One last note: I personally don't like the look of the oils floating to the top when I pull the dip from the oven. I blot with paper towel to remove most of the excess oil and stir the dip into a serving bowl garnishing it with a bit more shredded parm making it picture perfect.

text:
Followed to the T first time, but do agree...the flavor of the jarred Alfredo sauce came through =-(

Last week, made same recipe IN A HURRY with What I had avail:
Defrosted 9-10 oz chopped spinach in a 8X8 Pyrex-squeezed liquid out.
Added only 3/4 of Classico-Roasted Garlic Alfredo, 'only' 2/3 of a cup of Jarred marinated artichoke hearts(Very strong but buttery when chopped)2 tb of it's marinade, 3-6tb milk, pinch or 2 of pepper flakes and Marjoram (MAJOR TASTE IMPROVEMENT!) 8oz reduced fat cream cheese cubed, 1/3C parmegiano-regiano cheese, 2/3C mozzarella and 1/3C colby for color. Microwaved it at -50% Power -covered, stirring every 2 min until creamy and bubbly .
WONDERFUL!!!

userID:
5036919
Display Name:
pinki217
isPro:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
With the modifications, I absolutely love this recipe! This is a great base without the sour cream mayo that many recipes recommend. Since Thanksgiving, I've made this recipe 3 times--yes, it's that good. Tips that I would give: use fresh (baby) spinach if available, definitely roast the garlic (doesnt take that long).. I tend to put the garlic in the oven, heat up the alfredo sauce ( Classico 4 cheese, I think I'm going to try the roasted red pepper next time), drain rinse and chop the artichokes and finely chop the spinach, my secrets for this recipe are to add salt, pepper, and for kicks I add jalapeno chiles and Indian red chili powder (paprika works as well).. while the alfredo sauce is heating (I think mine is 15 oz and I use all of it, it reduces in quantity upon heating), I put the chopped spinach, artichokes, take out the garlic and add that it in there, and add the chopped picked jalapeno slices  and add most of the mozzarella and parmesan (i added pepperjack in there today as well, it was quite good), and add the cream cheese, then finally add the hot sauce which melts and molds everything together, making it easy to mix. I spread this on the pan and add the remaining cheese.. the jalapenos do make a huge difference and heating the alfredo is key for a spreadable mixture!

text:
I didn't give it 4 stars, which would indicate a good recipe if not great, because I had to tweak it so much. It might have been my own fault as I read other reviews about using Classico roasted garlic Alfredo as opposed to regular Alfredo, and I thought "yum! that sounds good!". However after it was made, and I put a spoonful in the microwave to taste test it, the dip was pretty darn flavorless. Yes, it was garlic-y but there was a lot of flavor missing to make it right to serve at a party, and it was EXTREMELY thick. So I threw in another 1/3 cup of parmesan - which I grated fresh hoping it would give it a kick. Threw a dab in the microwave, tried it again, still a no go. So I added 1/8 tsp cayenne pepper and 1 tbsp whipping cream to "loosen" up the dip. Heated it, tried it - still not quite there. Finally I threw in close to a whole cup of Sharp Cheddar cheese and a dash more cayenne pepper. Tried it, it was decent finally so I quit. It's OK. Not good or great like I thought it would be from the tons of reviews. Next time I'll use plain Alfredo, probably Ragu, and plain ol' garlic just like the original recipe calls for. If its better (which I hope it is) I'll come back a change my review.

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2780784.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is gooey, stringy and delicious. I used baked garlic, the entire 8 oz. block cream cheese, the 15 oz. jar Bertolli mushroom Alfredo sauce, 1 1/2 cups Sargento Mozzarella/Provolone, 1/2 c. Sargento shredded Parmesan. I added Tabasco and nutmeg. Left it overnight to develop the flavors. Baked it in a small Crockpot 1 hour on high 2 hours on low. Served with toasted baguette slices. 

I could see adding sauteed wild mushrooms or more artichoke hearts. This would also be good as stuffing for mushroom caps topped with buttered bread or panko crumbs or crispy fried shallots or onion rings.

text:
I strongly recommend reading several reviews to see how people changed the recipe. 

Changes I made: I did not roast the garlic, I used a bag of Italian blend cheese, I used the whole block of cream cheese, I only used half of the alfredo sauce.

I threw everything in my baby crockpot on high and stirred frequently. I was making it for an office party so I started it when I got to the office and it was ready by the time of our luncheon. Everyone loved it and I went home with an empty crockpot!

text:
A hit at the party.  You really have to use the REFRIGERATED Alfreodo sauce.  I even chose the "light"version.  And use 2 cups of mozzorella to get that 6 inches-string-effect. Make sure the artichoke is in "water".  Some brined artichoke brands are too salty and it will ruin this recipe.  Some commented on using half of the spinach.  I don't think so. And use the whole block (8 oz) of cream cheese.

The best recipe I have found for this dip so far...I halfed the recipe because I was making it for two and it was more than enough.  We had the rest the next day. The key is the alfredo sauce. I used Roasted Garlic Classico.  A real winner!

I made this recipe according to the directions but took others advice and used chopped garlic from a jar instead of roasting it. I used the whole package of cream cheese, and also used 2 cups of mozzarella and almost 1 cup of parmesan. At first I used less parm but it was a little bland and I thought the additional parmesan would add a little salt. I also added atleast a tablespoon of fresh ground pepper. To be honest, it was really good but it needed a little more flavor/kick. I think next time I will play around with reducing the alfredo sauce (it made it a little TOO creamy) and maybe adding a jalapeno or even cayenne. I thought the amount of spinach and artichoke was just right. Thanks for the recipe and all the tips!

I've brought this to work twice and it has been devoured both times.  This time, I doubled it and it STILL was gone before Noon!  I use roasted garlic alfredo which gives it the right amount of garlic flavor for my taste, so I nix the cloves.  I use the whole block of cream cheese, blend everything together and add a handfull of extra mozzarella before baking.  If I'm taking it somewhere, I transfer to a crock pot and keep it on low.  I serve with toasted mini bread chips that you can buy bagged. It's VERY creamy and the flavor is fantastic.

text:
Very rich and high in calories but very good.  (My spouse and I ate so much that we both had stomachaches, so pace yourself!)

I don't think it makes that huge of a batch.  The two of us ate it and had leftovers, but I would probably double it for a party.  

I think this would be better with fresh spinach, and maybe 15 oz. rather than 10 oz. of spinach. I like the fresh-tasting spinach dip from the Cheesecake Factory, so that's what I;m going for.

Outstanding...As good if not better than dishes found in a restaraunt. I followed the recipe layering the ingredients in the order stated. After the cooking time in the recipe, I uncovered the dish and mixed it up completely with a spoon. I then returned it to the oven, uncovered for an additional 15 minutes. The result was a slightly crusty top with a nice creamy interior. Perfect!!!

This turned out as good as most restaurant versions of this dip.  I did like others suggested and chopped the spinach and artichokes in a food processor-which is good so you don't end up with huge pieces of spinach or artichokes in the dip.  The store only had marinated artichokes, so the artichoke flavor was a little stronger, but I like artichokes so that was alright with me.  Next time I am going to add some extra cheese on top and broil it after baking it to get the top nice and golden.

text:
Yum!  I used the entire 8 oz of cream cheese, marinated artichokes and 1/2 jar of Bertolli creamy alfredo sauce.  Don't be afraid to use all 4 cloves of garlic.  That zip is needed.  Once the dip was heated through, I removed the lid & broiled for a couple of minutes.  Gave it a nice brown bubbly top.  Rather expensive to make, so save it to treat yourself or the people you really like.

text:
Very good and I will definitely make again with a couple of additions.   I added about 1/4 cup of onion, 8 or 9 drops of Tabasco sauce and 1/2 teaspoon of Sriracha sauce.    I really don't think the roasting of the garlic is a necessary step and could as easily be done by mincing the garlic and adding to the rest of the mixture and baking.   I also used the full 8oz block of cream cheese.  We served with beer bread and I had about 50/50 comments about those who preferred beer bread with it and those that preferred chips.

text:
You have to, have to, have to roast the garlic like the recipe calls for.  Roasted garlic has a significantly different flavor than raw garlic & it contributes greatly to the end product!  I used about 7 cloves of garlic, a whole 16oz jar alfredo-sauce, a little extra spinach & the whole pkg of cream cheese.  I baked it covered for 30 minutes, then uncovered & baked another 10, then broiled about 3 minutes on low to lightly brown the top.  Very good with tortilla chips or wheat thins!

text:
This recipe was Perfect! EXACTLY what I have been looking for!   I used a cheesy Ragu alfredo sauce, Roasted Garlic and Parmesan flavored. There was a very nice presence of garlic in the sauce, so I only used 1 clove of garlic instead of 4. Also, I read some reviews and took the suggestion to use the whole package of cream cheese instead of half. I also sprinkled some additional parm and mozarella cheeses on top before sticking it in the oven. It was EXQUISITE! It was Very moist and creamy, yet not too runny. It works Perfectly with Tollhouse crackers.  One suggestion that I was going to do (but forgot to) was add a bit of dill weed.   Between all 7 people who ate it (including myself) it was gone in a flash. I am not looking elsewhere for a recipe for spinach and artichoke dip. This is the one I am standing by! It was EXACTLY what I have been looking for.

country:

text:
BEST EVER. I thought I might be copping out by adding alfredo, but it was just so dang tasty. 

I used Bertolli's Roasted Garlic Alfredo from the jar. I've also used minced garlic instead of roasted garlic a few times, just to save time, and it didn't make too much of a difference. Sometimes I don't have shredded parmesan and leave it out.. I don't notice a difference.

I've also made this recipe in my fondue pot, using minced garlic instead and it's just as good, if not better!

One time I used the whole bag of Mozz though.. big mistake. Stick to the recipe and you'll be delighted!

And if you have extra time, mix the garlic, spinach and artichokes in a container and let them meld together overnight. I did this for Thankgiving and the dip was even more amazing.

I've made this several times and everyone LOVES it. A few people have even said that they HATED spinach and artichoke dip before this one! :)

None
country:
None
text:
I'm one of those people who has to bring food to a party, and this looked interesting,  so after reading the reviews, blah blah blah, this is what I did: I used the whole 8oz block of cream cheese, which I creamed with a heaping tablespoonful of chopped garlic(in place of the roasted), and squeezed the spinach dry by wrapping in clean paper towel and twisting gently. The artichokes seemed to have some tough pieces as I was chopping them, so I threw those pieces out. I mixed everything together in a bowl with a pinch of cayenne pepper and a tsp of granulated garlic (you can't have enough) and refrigerated it overnight, dumped everything in a small crock pot and turned it on high for an hour before the office party. It  scored rave reviews. We mounded it on sturdy crackers or bagel chips. Some people just ate it with a spoon! I will be making this many more times. Oh by the way, the Boss loved it! Added note: I recommend using Bertolli Roasted Garlic Alfredo sauce. I made this on 12/20/2018 and used a 6.5 oz jar of Gioia brand marinated artichokes, drained and chopped, and I believe it was even better tasting!

country:
None
text:
I never follow recipes I always add a little something something. For this I followed recipe, then added a bag of mixed white cheeses (asiago, provolone, etc.) I believe Sargento makes it. Then I add seasoning salt, pepper, garlic powder. I also use a whole package of cream cheese and whole container of Classico 4 cheese alfredo. First I take the artichoke and spinach and mince them in a food processor. When they become small enough to liking I dump them in a bowl. I pour in ingredients by the halves while taste testing to check what it needs more of. Once mixed to your liking then I throw it in a crock pot and walk away. (depending on how soon you need it crank that bad boy up. But if you make it early and don't need it asap let it simmer on low until ready. This will make the dip even better!). Overall I absolutely love the recipe but like all recipes you need to fine tune it to your tastes.

userID:
3196049
Display Name:
Amanda Nerud
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5923968.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dip for a Halloween party on 10/26/13 and then AGAIN for a wedding shower I hosted on 10/27/13 (the 26th was a dry run to see if it was any good!).  There was about a cup left when the parties were over - just enough for me for later! I had read the good (and bad) reviews and prepared myself for anything - but by the rave reviews on the spot, their plates being thrown away empty, and the small amount leftover, I'd say it was a hit!

I did adjust the ingredients in the manner:
-Used a grocery store prepared minced roasted garlic (about 2-2.5 tsp = 4 cloves of garlic) 
-Used Bertolli's Garlic Alfredo sauce
-Used entire package of cream cheese
-Used 1/2 c of parmesan cheese

I adjusted the prep directions in this manner:
-I didn't have to prep the garlic, so that saved a TON of time.
-I mixed all ingredients in a bowl WELL - the cream cheese, if not soft will not mix well and will lack flavor, it needs to be mixed together to get all the flavors in love!
-I cooked it till bubbly (about 20 min) and then dumped it into a crock pot on warm (or low) for long-time serving.

If you have leftovers, I recommend reheating with a little bit of milk (it probably condensed down some in the crock pot) and then you can top with cheese for yummy seconds!

I will make this again for work potlucks, my friends love Spin-art Dips! :)

text:
YUM!!!! I can't give this enough stars! I'm a huge fan of a certain casual restaurant chain's spinach and artichoke dip but I hated getting it because it's so expensive. I came across this recipe and I wasn't sure about the alfredo sauce but thought I'd give it a shot. I made a double batch and used Newman's Own and Bertolli Roasted Garlic flavored Alfredo sauce in the jar. I also added a container of the philadelpia garlic cooking cream along with regular cream cheese as well. I did this so I didn't have to mess with roasting garlic but I'd still have the flavor. 

This stuff was so good I seriously gave myself a horrid stomachache because I could not stop devouring it. I did have to add a little bit of spices to it to give it a bit more flavor, I also added a smidge of sour cream too. Don't get me wrong it was good with out any additions, I just wanted it to have a little more kick. I can't remember what spices I used exactly but I just read over other recipes and incorporated a mixture of what they used. 

I took this with me to a family gathering and everyone loved it. It makes a lot though and I definitely did not need a double batch that's for sure. I will make this again for sure in the future. Right now I can't even bear to look at if since I ate so much of the darn stuff.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/708743.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Creamy, garlicky, and delicious! I followed the recipe, except I used roasted garlic alfredo sauce (unrefrigerated) instead of 4 cloves garlic to save time. Also, I mixed all ingredients in a bowl, then poured into a baking dish so everything was evenly blended. It baked up all gooey and bubbly, and everyone at my Super Bowl party loved it. Serve with Triscuits for some nice salt flavor to balance the creaminess! 

Note: thaw the spinach WAY in advance of making the dip. I tried to rush the process by rinsing under hot water in a strainer, and then leaving it to soak in a bowl of hot water, and though it effectively thawed the spinach, it did create a huge mess in my sink and on my hands. If you let it thaw overnight or for a few hours ahead of time, you'll save yourself a headache during prep.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/312901.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night as an appetizer for my boyfriend and I. Delicious!  I love Applebee's Spinach and Artichoke Dip and this is just as good, if not better.  Like most other reviewer, I used the whole 8 oz package of cream cheese.  If you are a calorie counter, I'm sure buying 1/3 fat or light cream cheese would not affect the taste at all.  The only other things I did different was gave it three splashes of Frank's Hot Sauce and one splash of lemon juice on the spinach.  Warmed the cream cheese a bit, mixed all the cheeses together and then mixed in the spinach and artichokes.  Added some course ground black pepper before baking.  Oh, and I used a tablespoon of butter and sauteed about 2 tsp of minced garlic until browned and it turned out just fine, so personally I don't think roasting whole cloves for 20 minutes is necessary at all.  Delish! Thanks for an excellent recipe!

text:
This is a great recipe! I altered it just a lil for a double batch and added sour cream(needed some zing)...2 boxes frozen chopped spinach, 1 16 oz jar alfredo sauce (4 cheese), 2/3 C grated parm, 2 C mozz., 2 cans artichoke hearts, 4 tsp minced fresh garlic, tsp salt (to taste) and 1/2 C sour cream. Save a lil of the cheese to sprinkle on top before baking. Serve with Tortilla chips. IT WAS A HUGE HIT!!!

text:
This was a simple recipe to follow, and the end result tasted great! Not exactly like what I've had in restaurants, but it still tasted great. I had always gotten spinach & artichoke dip at restaurants, but never thought to make it myself. Also, about 10 minutes before I took it out of the oven, I sprinkled a handful of mozzarella cheese on top to melt, it turned out great! Served it with tortilla chips. I would also suggest mixing the ingredients around very well before baking, as I found a few pockets of cheese once it was done baking, which wasn't a big deal and could be remedied by stirring it up again once it was out of the oven.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this at least a dozen times and I love it. You do not have to use the Italian mix, you can use just parm. cheese but it should be fresh. I use almost the entire jar of alfredo to keep it from being too thick. Also, I use a 16oz frozen bag of spinach and throw the frozen artichokes in the food processor first. Mix all the ingredients together and use the entire cream cheese package. Use Bertoli or Trader Joe's alfredo sauce, not Ragu. The roasted garlic is not mandatory, I just use fresh minced garlic. It always turns out great and everyone inhales it. Good with tortilla chips, garlic toast, carrots- anything to dip!

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2007-08-02T12:58:45.7
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
2445021
Display Name:
ArmyWife1122
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I searched the web for a recipe like this since I went to Macaroni Grill and had their Spinach Shrimp Artichoke dip.  I like others who posted before mixed all the ingredients together.  I also used the whole portion of cream cheese (I used an 8oz tub of whipped cream cheese), and used a whole 15oz jar of Bertolli Alfredo sauce.  I buy my fresh garlic weekly and grind it a bit in the food processor with a little bit of olive oil so I always have it on hand for cooking, so I couldn't roast my garlic in the oven.  Instead I took about 1 1/2 Tbsp of the chopped garlic and sauteed it on the stove in a teaspoon of olive oil until it just lightly browned.  This worked out perfectly and saved me about 20-30 minutes.  I also added about half a cup of cooked salad shrimp to the recipe since that is the dip I was looking for.  I served it with a loaf of baguette bread sliced up.  Last night was my first time making this dish, and it is already a family favorite.  This recipe definately rocks.

Great for leftover dip.

text:
This dip was fantastic and very easy to prepare. I served it a party and everyone was asking me for the recipe. I kept the recipe the same for the most part, but since I'm in Mexico, I had to use ingredients that are locally available. Instead of mozzarella cheese, I used Manchego cheese and I couldn't find plain alfredo sauce, so I used a sun-dried tomato alfredo sauce that was available, instead.  The only thing I'll do differently next time is to put the spinach and artichokes into a food processor first so that the dip has a smoother texture.  Great dip, thanks for sharing it with us.

text:
I have been serving this one for years.  I use this general recipe with a few revisions. I add 1 small jar marinated, chopped artichoke hearts, 1 teaspoon onion powder and use Monterey jack instead of Mozzerella cheese).  I also save the juice from the marinated artichoke hearts just in case the dip needs thinning.  I also serve it with vegetable "dippers"... I use a zig-zag slicer to cut a large carrot and zucchini into "coins" for a pretty, lower carb dipping option.  I served it while catering last week and got more business from it!  Tons of rave reviews!  (I have to be fair: 4 stars for this recipe, 5 stars for my version)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a tasty dip.  I've made it with the garlic roasted and also raw and it's good either way.  I found that roasting individual cloves of garlic the way it's described here can result in overdone "crunchy" garlic.   Better to roast an entire bulb of garlic (double wrapped in foil with a bit of olive oil) and have extra to spread on bread.   Finally, I sprinkle some extra cheese on top of it and bake for another few minutes - it's more attractive that way.

Great recipe!  I made this for a New Years Party and it was a big hit!!  I used a whole package of cream cheese instead of half (by mistake) and it was really creamy. Very easy to make and very good! This recipe is a keeper!!

text:
Made this for our annual holiday party and it was a big hit. I will now add it to my menu every year. I cooked it in a small crock pot for it to stay warm as guests arrived. To the crock pot, I added Bertoli Roasted Garlic Alfredo (as another reviewer suggested) along with the mozzarella, Parmesan and cream cheeses (I used the entire 8oz of cream cheese). I finely chopped the spinach and artichokes. I then added a tablespoon of minced garlic and a teaspoon of garlic powder. My crock pot only as one setting so I started it one hour before the party and served with Stacys Simple Naked pita chips.

I've tried a couple of dozen spinach artichoke dips over the last few years; and this is the one closet to a restaurants here that I love.  .It's important to roast the garlic.  I used the whole 8 oz of cream cheese and added a little kick with some Tabasco sauce. The first time I left the artichokes to big and people picked them out.  Second time made sure they were chopped fine and it was perfect.  I also made my own Alfredo why ruin it with store bought junk...Â½ cup (1 stick) butter, 1 Â½ cups grated Parmesan cheese, 1 cup (8 oz) heavy cream (or more), Â¼ cup chopped fresh parsley, Â¼- Â½ tsp garlic powder, opt. Â¼- Â½ tsp ground black pepper, opt. Yummy  Serve with corn chips and a good bread. I made a triple batch and I also had to thin it out a few times during the party with more cream in the warmer to keep it the creamy texture I wanted. Don't layer just mix it all together...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! This dish is amazing! This is the best artichoke and spinach dip I've ever had! A few tips and alterations: roast an entire head of garlic (I know, but it's good) by cutting the top off, putting it on foil, pouring a little olive oil on, sealing it and baking it in the oven for about an hour on 200 degrees. After it's cooled, squeeze out the roasted garlic cloves and add that to the ingredients. Use two packages of spinach, two cans of artichoke hearts, two containers of Bertolli Alfredo sauce, add Romano cheese, and use the full 8 ounces of cream cheese. Mix all of the ingredients in a bowl, and then transfer the mixture to a baking dish. PERFECTION!

text:
We LOVE this dip.  WE as in my family and cowokers for myself anf my spouse and the kids at school.  I roast  the garlic and a handful of shallots al drizzled in olive oil. I give them a whirl i processor before adding.  I also use refrigerated Bertolli because it has a better flavor.   I added  3 Tbs chopped water chestnuts andI use 2 c. moz cheese and 8oz cream cheese.  I leave the rest as is.  I mix it all together then spread it in a pan to bake/toast, serve it in a bread bowl and top with French's fried onions for aesthetics.  I t is dreamy delicious good and I have tried NUMEROUS recipes for this dip.  We like tortilla chips and pita chips wihit the most!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe but I wouldn't exactly call it restaurant quality. It seemed to lack something and I can't quite put my finger on what it is yet. It was still a hit none the less and I will continue to make this recipe and adjust it to my own taste until it "feels" right. It could be as simple as using higher quality ingredients. Just a note to those of you using a crockpot, use a cooking spray before pouring in your ingredients. Also, I had to put my crockpot on high for about maybe an hour before the consistency was just right. When I first tried it (20 min. into heating) it was stringy instead of creamy. I was worried I had done something wrong and it wouldn't turn out for the party I needed to bring it to. So make sure you give yourself just a little time before serving this. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
My dip is a little watery, but I think that's because all of my calculations were off. :/ I sent someone else to get the ingredients and my measurements were off as a result. I was low on spinach so I think that was the culprit. Other than that, the flavor was great! I think next time I'll roast more garlic, 4 gloves just didn't seem enough for my taste.

***The day after the party I had some dip left, so I took some chilled crescent rolls and put the remaining dip inside. They were excellent! Just roll them up and back them and 375 for about 25-20 minutes.

text:
This dip is by far the BEST spiniach dip I've ever had! For holidays/parties I usually get stuck making a cold version with sour cream and mayo, but this year I wanted something different. The alfredo sauce really scared me and I actually saved this but kept looking. Boy am I glad I came back to this one! Everyone devoured it, saying it was the best they've ever had! I did use a full pack of cream cheese according to reviews and also not so much artichoke (preference), and Im a garlic lover so I used 6-7 cloves. Layering? Um I just mushed it all up :) & if you dont have time to roast the garlic, like my second time around, don't worry it still tastes delicious! All in all dont be afraid to try this unique recipe! You won't be sorry!!

text:
I liked this recipe. I did change some things according to other reviews, I used the 15oz jar of alfredo sauce, bertolli and i used 1/2 cup of parm cheese. Also I used the whole 8oz pack of cream cheese. I mixed all the ingrediants together before adding them to my pan. My husband didnt like it at all he said way to much artichoke. Next time I will use 1/2 the can of artichoke and rinse it really well before hand.Also I will try to chop up the artichoke a little better. It also needs some salt and pepper to taste.All and all I liked it, tasted sort of like cheddars. Oh and I also added some tomatoes to my bowl of dip to  make it extra good. Im going to make it again for Christmas with my few adjustments. Thanks for this recipe.

text:
I've made this twice. The first time, I followed the recipe, except I mixed all of the ingredients together before putting it in the oven. It tasted pretty bland to me because of the jarred alfredo sauce. The next time, I prepared one package of the McCormick garlic alfredo sauce. It became the best spinach and artichoke dip I've ever had. I would recommend either using the McCormick package or making your own alfredo sauce. Definitely make sure to mix everything together before you bake it.

text:
I made this for a family gathering.  Everyone really enjoyed it.  I followed the suggestions of some reviewers & used refrigerated alfredo sauce, 1/2 cup parmesan and the entire 8-0z. package of cream cheese.  I drained the spinach & pressed out the remaining liquid.  The flavor was good but not as pronounced as I would have preferred so I'll reduce the cream cheese to the original amount next time.  I added 3 Tbs. milk since the mixture seemed too thick.  I'll leave the extra spinach liquid when I make it again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/270727.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree with previous reviews that this dip was way too bland.  The next day, my husband and I pulled it out of the fridge, zapped in the microwave, stirred in a bit of onion and garlic powder, salt, and pepper, and it was a million times better.  I think if I had used an alfredo sauce that had garlic flavor already or marinated artichoke hearts it would have helped, but honestly, it needed the salt more than anything.  My husband agreed that it lacked something to be desired.  So with a little doctoring, it's pretty good.  But definitely not the best I've ever had.  I would suggest adding about a 1/2 tsp of salt, 1/4 tsp pepper, and at least a 1/2 tsp each of garlic and onion powder before baking.  I also added a little pimento on top before baking and it added a little color and flavor.

I was trying to come up with a good spinach artichoke dip that I could make ahead and reheat for my daughters graduation party. After reviewing other comments and recipes, this is what I came up with. I added 8 slices of bacon (per my daughters request), a whole brick of cream cheese and a whole jar of alfredo. I think using the whole jar of alfredo is the key to reheating it and having it remain creamy.  I think I gained about 2 lbs testing it!! So easy and so good.

text:
I made this for a Christmas party and everyone devoured it! Since I had some picky eaters coming, I skipped out on the roasted garlic and used a sauce mix for garlic alfredo sauce instead. I also doubled the recipe by simply doubling the amount of spinach and cream cheese. I was afraid it might need more cheese or additional alfredo, but it ended up just  fine! It was a big hit! I made it in the oven and served it in a mini crock pot that was made for keeping hot dips warm. I left the rest in the oven (with the oven off) and refilled throughout the night. I was surprised how popular it was. I served it with toasted French bread and tortilla chips as well. Even the picky eaters said it was their absolute favorite! Can't wait to make again!

This recipe is very good, I followed it pretty much to a "t" (didn't drain the spinach and am glad b/c it provided enough liquid that this was scoopable and spreadable) and received many compliments and comments such as "this is better than what we find in restaurants"... so it does live up to it's name. text:
For those complaints regarding flavor, use flavored cream cheese; either the garlic and onion flavored cream cheese or the vegetable-garden flavored cream cheese.  I always substitute one of those and I also use the whole container of cream cheese. I will also substitute and use "light" products to try and help the calorie count! I also serve it with vegetables (carrots, celery, red, yellow or orange pepper strips, brocolli.) No other complaints, it is a richer appetizer, but non one complains!   I LOVE the ease of it, and the ability to pre make and put in fridge or freezer.

I also left out the parmesan and used Bortelli's Garlic and parmesan alfredo...it was great and the re-heated leftovers are wonderful!

userID:
2571174
Display Name:
chanchitis
isPro:

1

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  So easy and delicious!  Since it was my first time making this, I mixed it all in a bowl and microwaved it, just to check the flavor before I baked it, and I realized that it's delicious microwaved!  I took everyone's advice and added the whole block of cream cheese.  Also, I used Bertolli Roasted Garlic Alfredo (the whole jar) PLUS 4-5 cloves roasted, mashed garlic, 1 C Mozzarella, 1 C parmesan, 1 1/4 Cups Cabot sharp white cheddar (the cheddar really sharpened it up; it was a little flat before), 1 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes, 1 tsp black pepper.  I also microwaved the frozen spinach first, then squeezed out all the extra water.  The only other thing that was different was that I thinned the dip with milk, maybe 2 - 3 cups.  It was too stretchy and goopy without it.  Then again, I added a lot of extra cheese!

text:
We really enjoyed this. It tasted better than restaurant dip. I put my spinach, roasted garlic, and artichokes in the food processor because I don't like the chunks. It gives it a great texture. I mix everything in my stand mixer to eliminate cream cheesy clumps. I also followed the advice of some other reviewers and used all of the cream cheese and Alfredo sauce. I use Garlic Alfredo to give it a little extra flavor. (Since my original review, I've gotten lazy. I don't roast the garlic anymore and notice no difference.)    I make this pretty often. I have taken it to several parties and gotten tons of compliments on it. It usually doesn't last more than 10 minutes!   I had to update: I have had at least 6 people ask for this recipe. It's such a huge hit! People request this ALL the time. I've taken to doubling the recipe because I know one batch just isn't enough!

I too used the whole block of cream cheese, regular (not roasted) minced garlic (from the jar), and mixed it all up instead of layering.  I did use real, freshly grated parmesean and you could definetly taste it (in a good way!).  Will definetly be making this again - next time I may use an italian blend of grated cheese instead of just mozzarella.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is easy and very yummy! I read a majority of the reviews and made the following recommended adjustments: roasted the garlic (used 5 cloves instead of 4), used a garlic flavored alfredo sauce, as well as the entire package of cream cheese, added 1 cup mozzarella cheese and 1 cup colby, jack, and monterey cheese mix and then used a hand mixer to mix it all together before baking. It was a big hit at the party (got a lot of requests for the recipe) but my husband thought it was almost too garlic-ey (and he likes garlic!) but that may have been because my sister-in-law served garlic pita chips with the dip. I didn't think the garlic was overwhelming but next time I may just use 4 cloves of garlic and try a regular alfredo mix. Overall I was very happy with the way it turned out and will definitely make it again (it makes quite a bit, by the way).

As I do with most recipes I modified this one a little... I used 16 oz of alfredo sauce, 2 cups mozzarella, the entire block of cream cheese, and 5 cloves of garlic. It came out WONDERFULLY! However, it was a tad bland. But my boyfriend thought that it was wonderful, and I'm used to the REALLY strong dips so it might have been just right, just not for me ;) Next time I make it I will add more garlic and more parmesan... they both seem to spice it up a bit. Overall, this dip was great, and definitely a favorite of my family's.

text:
This is my go to recipe. I cook the garlic differently because cooking it in a baking pan dries it out a bit. 
Take the skins off the garlic and cut the ends. Wrap them in a foil ball and cook until mushy. Then I make a paste and place it in the dip. 
Roasted garlic is a must in this recipe!
-Use the whole thing of cream cheese 
-use Bertolli Alfredo sauce 
-dump everything in the crock pot instead of baking because itâ€™s just so much easier!

I have been making this recipe for the last three years, since I first found it here. Friends demand it for football games, parties and potlucks and I have never made it for less then 50 servings. Took this to a neighborhood get together and it was devoured. Everyone loved and requested I make it more often. I used a 15 oz jar of alfredo and the chunk of cream cheese I had was only 3 oz. I didn't have fresh garlic so I added a couple of tablespoons of minced from a jar and about 1/4 tsp garlic powder. I eyeballed the parmesan and added a good bit extra to the top before baking.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2012-03-16T12:14:46.373
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
8197083
Display Name:
Tracy Moudry
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
15
favoritesCount:
89
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1284537.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
8 oz Philadelphia cream cheese 
1.5 cups mozzarella cheese
1 tsp garlic powder
1 Tbsp Adobe all purpose seasoning
10oz Frozen spinach, thawed and drained

Mix, in that order within a large bowl while oven is preheating. Pour into 9x9 baking pan and cook until edges are bubbly. Stir and top with extra cheese and freshly diced tomatoes as desired for presentation. 

***Steam fresh spinach makes this recipe MUCH easier. Just microwave for half the time labeled on the bag and drain.

text:
i wanted to try a new recipe and this one had so many good reviews but I was pretty disappointed.  I used half the spinach suggested, 2c of mozzarella, 1/2c of parmesan, 8oz of cream cheese, a 15oz jar of roasted garlic alfredo and a whole can of artichoke hearts.  I didn't add any salt but it was extremely salty maybe because of the store bought alfredo sauce. It wasn't as creamy as I thought it would be even though I heated all of the ingredients together before baking so that it would be evenly distributed.  Although this is much easier to make than my other SA recipe, I'd have to make more adjustments to this one before it can be up to par with my other recipe.

text:
Have only received compliments when making this dish.  I mix all the ingredients together, not layering, and use fresh spinach (sauted & drained).  My favorite way of making this dish is taking tortilla wraps, cutting them in small squares, spray a mini muffin tray with olive oil and form the tortilla squares in the muffin tray.  Fill with the spinach artichoke dip and bake for approx 5-10 min.  I put on broil the last couple of minutes.

text:
I'm a garlic addict so I added 4 large elephant garlic bulbs of garlic chopped finely. I also added some real lump crab meat (WARNING! CRAB MEAT: A TINY BIT GOES A VERY LONG WAY!) and additional cream cheese Also, the bake time on this dip is WAY off. Go higher and longer, until fully bubbling! Other than that, I followed this recipe to a tee. Seriously people, this recipe was to die for! Folks, this is one of those recipes you'll steal and tell your guests, "Yeah, one night I got bored and created it myself." This tasted FAR better than Papaduex (the chain restaurant) recipe! By the way, I only had some Ragu Alfredo Sauce on hand and it still turned out great! I can only imagine how wonderful this recipe would be with a higher end Alfredo sauce!

userID:
4553599
Display Name:
Joyce Chan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3345454.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first time I made the  recipe and  it was   wonderful just like restaurant style.  I read the reviews before I made this and I noticed people saying it wasnt thick enough in some cases or it didnt have the right consistency.  So to make  it blend very well I used a food processor... I  chopped   frozen chopped spinach 16oz,  and canned artichokes ( not marinated ones) in the processor first then I   hit the mix  button until I saw it was mixed well then I added the   whipped cream  cheese 8oz in there as well and mixed that up.  While  I was doing this I  did  bake 1 whole bulk of garlic in the oven... and did as  directed  on the  recipe,  squeezed all that garlic out there.   
 When I was  done with  the processor i threw all the  ingredients  in the a large mixing  bowl, then added the regular alfredo ( used trader joes) ,   mixed it up then  added the  garlic mixed that up then  for  cheeses I used   1/3 parm/romano  (50/50 blend) as that was what i had on hand,  and 1 1/2 cup of mozzarella...   and mixed  it up together. It was thick by the time I mixed everything together. I poured it in 8x8 baking dish.   Baked  it for   30 minutes and it was amazing!  I got most of my ingredients from trader joes...  It was delicious, thick and cheesy!!!

This is awesome!  I really don't change any of the ingredients...just the amounts.  I always make a big pan (13x9) and double the garlic, cream cheese, and spinach. And, I just chop the garlic without baking it first.

text:
Like others, even though I would like to, I can't give full stars because I changed the recipe slightly. But WOW! this dip was fantastic!. I used one reviewer's suggestion and used garlic powder (1 tablespoon) instead of cloves of garlic. We didn't have the time to roast the cloves. I also used a cup and a half of a Mozza-cheddar shredded cheese combo instead of just mozzarella.  We cut up some store bought naan for dipping. We had it for a midnight snack on New Years Eve. I think I will be making this again and again. And yes, it tastes EXACTLY like the fabulous dip they serve at Casey's restaurants in Ontario, Canada. YUMMYY!!!!

country:
None
text:
This is delicious! My husband and I had been looking for a great spinach artichoke dip and this definitely fits the bill. We made a few changes to suit our tastes: we used about 6 oz (3/4 package) cream cheese, a little extra mozzarella, and a dash of cayenne pepper. We also used minced garlic straight from the jar for convenience. We just mixed everything together in a bowl, spread it in a dish, and baked. I would suggest stirring it after 30 min of baking to get the cream cheese well distributed (ours was kinda clumped together at first), then popping it back in for a few minutes. So yummy with tortilla chips!

This was amazing!  It was okay right out of the oven, but if you let it sit overnight, the flavors mellow/meld and you end up with a dip that rivals Applebee's.  I'm used to paying $10 for a small bit of this at Applebee's.  Now I pay the same $10 and get 8X as much as I would buy at a restaraunt.  If you like spinach and artichoke dip, make this recipe.  You won't be sorry.

text:
I always get nervous when trying new recipes, but I had a craving for this kind of dip and decided to give this one a chance based on the high rating. I absolutely loved it, along with every single person who tried it. Everyone kept coming back for more. One of my guests honestly said "it's like a little taste of heaven". I did use the whole 8 oz package of cream cheese, and I'm really glad I did. Delicious!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the Hot Artichoke & Spinach Dip first from this website and the cream cheese was overwhelming.  So I tried this one and it's SO MUCH better.  I wanted the dip to be close/equal to restaurant quality because we always order it when we eat out and this version is very close.  I used shredded parmesan cheese instead of grated.  I've made this twice already and the 2nd time, I doubled the recipe for a family party.  Who would have thought the secret ingredient is a jar of Alfredo sauce!!  I used Bertolli the first time and Paul Neuman the second time.  Used garlic powder instead of real garlic to speed things up.  I added salt and pepper after it came out of the oven because I didn't know how salty the cheeses would be after they've melted.  I will be making this again and again.  I served it with tortilla chips and homemade garlic bread.  It's very good with bread.  Warning:  It's highly addictive!

It does not get any better than this! I followed the recipe exactly with one exception. I used other reviewers suggestions and used the entire thing of cream cheese and added extra alfredo sauce. I wanted to turn this into a dinner so I made pizza with it, so incredible! I used a premade pizza crust baked it for a couple of minutes, topped with the cooked artichoke spinach dip, some baby shrimp and extra mozz and parmesan cheese baked until the cheese was melted and garnished with some green onion. Sure not the healthiest recipe in the world but so delicious. Can't wait to make this again!

city:

text:
It was so easy to make. I whipped a batch up for a family party and impressed everyone- I of course had to admit it was amazingly simple. I was doing Christmas gifts on the cheap last year, but didn't want to do cookies for everyone (I didn't have enough time plus wanted to be more creative). So i made a batch of this for several people on my list- Made the entire thing on the stove top and instead of putting it in the oven, i put it in airtight ziploc containers, and refrigerated them. I gave them with heating instructions (added 10 minutes to the cooking time to make up for the fact that it was cold when going into the oven) and a bag of chips. I've made this so many times that I don't even need the recipe. It's ingrained in my mind.

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is so good, I finally registered here just to write a review. I've always laughed at reviews that say "this is the best recipe ever, and here's how I changed it..." but now it's my turn! Instead of roasting 4 cloves of garlic, I used minced garlic from a jar, equal to 4 cloves, without roasting. Instead of frozen spinach, I used chopped fresh spinach. (Note: Alfredo sauce from the refrigerated pasta section, not the pasta aisle.) Instead of layering, I mixed everything except the Parmesan cheese together in a bowl, then poured into the dish and topped with the Parmesan cheese. If you take this to a party, you WILL get asked for the recipe.

text:
This dip is fabulous.  Although I did make a few alterations.  Instead of using 4 cloves of garlic I just add in minced garlic that you buy in a glass jar approx. 2 tablespoons or however much you prefer more or less.  I bought the roasted garlic Alfredo Style Pasta Sauce by Ragu (I believe).  As well I added Salt and Pepper and a dash of garlic powder.  I mixed all the ingredients together instead of layering it.  Then I topped off with extra mozzarella and parmesan cheese. This is a great party dish for entertaining.

text:
This has become my signature dip-- I'm always asked to make it for parties! I use one full 8 oz. block of cream cheese, and instead of adding extra roasted garlic, I use most of a jar of Classico Roasted Garlic alfredo sauce. Make sure to mix all the ingredients together in a bowl before pressing it into a baking dish-- it incorporates the ingredients much better!

I have made the florentine artichoke dip from this site a few times, and thought it was pretty good, but this recipe tastes AMAZING!  I followed the recipe exactly, but I mixed all ingredients together and then spooned it into an 8x8 Pyrex dish.  I put some extra grated parmesan on top (I used the refrigerated kind, not the kind found in the pasta aisle), and baked it for about 40 minutes until the top was browned.  This is my new spinach artichoke dip recipe!

This is really an amazing dip.  I have made it twice.  This first time really just to "test" it out before a party.  With the first batch I did not change a thing. userID:
3286737
Display Name:
Christina Rust
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1616073.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AWESOME!  I made it for a Thanksgiving recipe with some of the recommended tweaks. 

I used preminced garlic to save on time, and it worked great.  I used a whole (15 oz) can of roasted garlic alfredo sauce.  I also upped the mozz cheese to 2 cups and the parm to 1/2 cup and used the whole 8 oz thing of cream cheese, (1/3 fat).

I used a bigger pan (13x9) and blended all the ingredents together with a mixer before placing in the pan.  It took closer to 45 minutes to bake at 350.  I would up the temp to 375 next time.

My own special tweak...
I sliced up a loaf of bagguette bread and mixed together margerine spread with about 1 tbs of minced garlic and 1/2 tbs itlian dressing.  I spread the butter mix on the bread and topped it with some parmeson, and sprinkled oregano and basil on top.  I toasted in the oven til browned and served with the dip.

Lots of potential here, but definitely not anything to rave about as is.

This stuff is SO good.  I went ahead and just used the entire 8 oz block of cream cheese, and an entire 15 oz jar of alfredo sauce.  I upped the mozzarella and parmesan accordingly, and I added about a half teaspoon of dried basil.  The recipe makes enough to completely fill an 8 x 8 baking dish.  People LOVE this stuff.  My mother-in-law wouldn't stop complimenting my dip, saying how much better it is than the restaurant's.  Thanks so much for this recipe!  I've tried the other recipe on this site that's just as popular, but uses mayo instead of alfredo sauce, and this one is MUCH better.

This is a new Thanksgiving tradition with my family as a dip for the football games!

text:
Awesome dip!  I am not a fan of mayo and I loved that this dip does not use it.  I followed others advice and used a whole package of cream cheese.  I also added cheddar cheese and was very generous with it and with the mozarella.  Finally, I used a Parmesan-Alfredo sauce instead of adding parmesan cheese.  Oh, I also used all low-fat or no-fat ingredients and it tasted wonderful!  I put all the ingredients in a bowl and mix with a hand mixer, bake for about 45 minutes, and then serve in a sweet hawaiin bread bowl- yum!

I, too, used the whole package of cream cheese.  I also went ahead and added the entirety of the 16-oz jar of alfredo sauce, and the whole 8-ounce package of shredded mozzarella (it was more than a cup).  I used raw garlic minced fine, and I added a few minced-up green onions and some canned nopalitos, drained and rinsed.  The resulting dip is so rich and creamy and good.  I like the bite of raw garlic, but I will not use as much next time; maybe just two cloves.

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-05-13T07:50:32.343

1
userID:
802795
Display Name:
Chelsey Wolnowski
isPro:
False
followersCount:
39
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
803
favoritesCount:
768
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4367.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I started off by saute-ing about half of a big red onion with lots of butter. (I know, so bad!) and some white wine. I then added the spinach and atrichoke hearts to that and continued to haet through. I addded my cream cheese and let it melt in. I didn't have any alfredo sauce, so I used a combination of Sour Cream (full fat to get the rich creamyness, though I'm sure low fat would still have tasted great) and some good Mayo. Finally I added the motzza and let that melt in, followed by the garlic. I put it in a casserole dish, and sprinkled with the Parm Cheese. Because I was taking it to a dinner party the next night, I covered it with saran wrap, and refridurated.  I decided to heat it through slowley in the oven before serving. I I just the oven to 325 and baked for about 25-30 mins. Great! :)
Review:
Rating:
1

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great and a big hit at my husband's office party.  I "tripled" the recipe as follows:  32oz frozen spinach, 16oz cream cheese, 32oz roasted garlic alfredo sauce, 5 tsp roasted garlic (from a jar), 4 cups mozzarella cheese, 7oz Kraft shredded parmesan/romano/asiago, 6oz real bacon bits, 3 (14oz) cans artichokes, and 1/2 cup milk to thin.  I stirred it all together and put in the crockpot on high for about 2 hours then turned to low.  Stir it occasionally and serve with tortilla chips.  This almost filled a 12 quart crockpot.  He didn't bring any home and had several requests for the recipe.  Will use this again and again.  Thanks!

text:
Simply outstanding! I have been looking for a true "restaurant style" spinach and artichoke dip for ages, and this beats them all hands down. You can lighten it up a bit successfully by using the 1/3 less fat cream cheese, part-skim mozzerella, and artichoke hearts packed in water instead of oil. Just make sure you add maybe 2 tsp. to 1 tblsp. italian seasoning or maybe 1 tsp. Mrs. Dash to make up for some of the flavor lost when you reduce fat. But it's still good, I promise!

text:
As Chandler would say: "OH,MY,GOD"  This recipe is great!!!  I looked and looked at all the recipes for this dip and decided on this one (because of the reviews).  My husband and I just finished it as a late night snack.  (Okay, we didn't finish ALL of it, but close!)  Anyway, here are my changes: Use fresh spinach (one bunch-cooked, then drained), mix everything together instead of layering, then after it's done cooking, sprinkle fresh parmesean cheese on top and put in the broiler for 10 additional minutes.  Beautiful browned cheese on top comes out, and the whole dip is excellent!  Thanks for the recipe!!!!!!!

text:
I have made this dish several times and even altered the amounts of alfredo, cream cheese, etc. due to the "what's available" factor.  You cannot go wrong! After it bakes, I usually broil it for a minute or two to give it that "restaraunt quality" look. I serve it with a mix of toasted and untoasted bagette slices (for textural variety) and serve the whole thing on a huge wooden cutting board.  It is always the first dish to disappear and the most frequently requested hors d'ouvre.

made it again this weekend using roasted garlic flavored alfredo...even better and cut the prep time!

This is absolutely foolproof.  I have always had variations on this dip come out dry.  I cook it in a heavy nonstick round cake pan and it makes a nice show when served on a big platter.  I add tons of garlic.  That's about all I changed.  I keep the Alfredo sauce in the pantry to make sure that I have the ingredients on hand.  My one variation, though, is to chop artichoke bottoms, because I don't like the stringiness of hearts.  I just cube them and they are perfect

region:

country:
None
text:
I loved the garlic in this but was a bit disappointed. I mixed ingredients together and then sprinkled with parmesan instead of layering like listed, I wanted to be able to taste the garlic through out and blend the cheeses. I baked for 30 min and it wasn't cooked, so took cover off and baked 10-15 min more. It was tasty but more thick and chunkier than what I like. I even used a little less spinach than stated. I love spinach and artichokes but I prefer a different recipe I have. Don't get me wrong, it was very tasty but just not creamy or saucy enough for us. Thanks TerraD!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good! Definitely roast the garlic and smudge on bottom of the dish. The most important thing I've noticed is that it's important to use a large enough dish. When I've poured into a cuter smaller dish, it never tastes as good. Allowing the dip to remain shallow in an 8x8 or larger dish ((ideally 11x7 or 13x9) ensures the roasted garlic flavor is distributed and the dish bubbles timely.I've actually halved the recipe before as well and that's great.

I live in Texas and all my ingredients were the HEB store brand.  I used the jar alfredo sauce (light version) and fat free cream cheese.  IT WAS A BIG HIT AT WORK,  It was basically all gone by the time our 12 hour shift ended.  The first time I made it I didnt buy the mozz cheese, I just grabbed the italian blend with asiago and parm.  It was still good. I just made it again for tonight at work using mozz cheese!  This will be the only spin dip recipe I will ever use!!!! I see that some people said to use the refrigerated sauce, and i will try that next time.  Even though I dont think the dip tasted weird with the HEB alfredo sauce.

text:
It is ok, others liked it more than I did. I read alot of the reviews and comments and made some adjustments - used entire brick of cream cheese, slightly increased mozzarella, used Classico roasted garlic alfredo sauce and cut out the real garlic. Overall it wasn't good or bad. I felt the alfredo sauce was very overpowering and it was all I could taste, if I make this again I would definitely not use the same sauce, maybe half a jar regular alfredo. To be completely honest I found a different recipe and threw this one away :(

On the bright side it is very easy to make and has a lot of room for making adjustments to suit your taste.

text:
Here's what I liked about this: it is healthier than most other spinach artichoke dips I've made in that it didn't call for mayo. The Alfredo sauce was a nice change and was not something I would have ever thought to use. What I changed about it: I used a whole package of cream cheese and I used two jars of Alfredo just because only one jar didn't look wet and loose enough to serve with tortilla chips (just personal preference). After taking it out of the oven, I put pico de gallo over the top of it to add another layer of flavor. The end result was amazing! You can also use fat free Alfredo sauce to cut a bit of calories.

text:
I made this for our Super Bowl party yesterday, and it was a huge HIT.  I used the 10 ounce refrigerated Alfred sauce, used the entire 8 oz of cream cheese, and 1 1/2 cups Mozzarella.  Oh, and I used 6 closed of garlic.  I had to bake the garlic the entire 30 minutes. I made it ahead of time and refrigerated it, took it out about 15 minutes before putting it in the oven, and baked it for about 45 minutes.  We will definitely be making this again.  Served with tortilla chips/crackers.

country:
None
text:
The first time I made this I used other reviewers suggestions and used garlic alfredo sauce to make things easier.  It turned out good, but the garlic and spinach was really strong. The second time  made it I used 1/4 less spinach, 1/4 more artichokes and I used 1/2 jar of regular alfredo sauce and 1/2 jar of garlic alfredo sauce. That solved everything and everyone LOVED it! I will definitely be making this over and over again! Oh and definitely follow the other reviewers suggestion and use the whole brick of cream cheese, it's sooooo good!

text:
I loved this.   Only thing I did , was use the whole 8 oz of cream cheese  and added 1 TBS of sour cream,
I used a soft Italian mix shred of cheese, ( all of I find at the time)  Ragu regular Alfredo sauce, and mine didn't take over the taste.   Everything else was exactly what the recipe said to do.  Also don't do this in the micro wave, do it in the oven like they recommend, I had to do mine a bit longer than 30 minutes.
I  sliced sour dough bread, ( one of those smaller ones) lightly buttered it then toasted it and served it with this dip
I sent some to the neighbor, and they asked me for the recipe

text:
This was amazing, we made a batch for a Christmas party and loved it so much we made another batch for another party the next day! I don't think anyone can go wrong with this recipe, this has become one of our entertaining staples :)

We made the following substitutions/variations:

We served this with plain tortilla chips
We used fresh spinach instead of frozen spinach
We used minced garlic (bottled) instead of garlic cloves
For the second batch, we tried it with half as much artichoke hearts
We used creamy Alfredo sauce for the first batch and three-cheese Alfredo sauce for the second one.

This was really spectacular!  The biggest tip I can give if making this is use an alfredo sauce that you really like.  Alfredo sauce makes up a huge part of this dip so obviously if you don't like jarred sauce, don't use jarred sauce! I mixed everything together in a bowl and threw it in the crockpot for New Years Eve.  Low for 3 hours to heat through and then put on warm.  Everyone loved this!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I hate store bought alfredo sauce.  I decided to give it a try using
 15 oz.Ragu garlic roasted parmesan alfredo sauce (entire jar) and used 1 8 oz 1/3 less fat cream cheese.  I used 1 cup mozz and 1/2 cup Italian 6 blend, 1/2 cup fresh grated parmesan.  I didn't have garlic cloves so I used 1 tsp garlic powder instead.   Sprinkled a little more parmesan and Italian blend cheese on top and baked it till lightly golden.  Awesome!!!  Did not taste like store bought sauce with these modifications.  Always tastes better the next day.  
My new go to recipe.  It's for a potluck and I am saving some for home.  Ha!

text:
So I get asked for this dish every single time I contribute to any event.  It simply is ALWAYS the dish that gets eaten, I have never had left overs with this dish. I often mix it up the night before, refrigerate it and bake it about 40 minutes before its time to attend the event.  I use 8 oz of cream cheese that I warm in the microwave to make it mix easier. And then when I'm done mixing I taste taste taste!!! And taste again!  Tasting before baking makes all the difference!!

text:
I've made this about 6 times. The first time I made it I had never cooked with garlic cloves, so it didn't turn out as good as the next 5 times I made it. So the 2nd time and everytime after, I used minced garlic (in the jar, name brand was spice world) I addded the equivlent of 6 garlic cloves... I don't think you can add too much garlic! I also used 2 full 8 oz packages of cream cheese and Buitoni alfredo sauce (from winn-dixie or publix) I actually used Olive Garden alfredo sauce once and it was amazing.... But everytime I have made it (even the 1st when it wasn't AS good) It was absolutely phenomenal. I made it for Thanksgiving and everybody loved it, a lot of people took some home too and called me that night and the next day saying how delicious it was!

None
country:
None
text:
I used minced garlic that I had on hand.. I know, I know, I cheated but this still turned out fantastic!  My niece said it was better than the same kind of dip they ordered at a restaurant before.  I think it is very important that you mix all the ingredients together before you put them in the dish to bake!  I added an extra cup of mozzarella and topped it with some shredded parmesan I had on hand.  After it baked in the oven for 30 minutes I put the oven on broil and let the top of it brown just a little.  There wasn't a bite left at the end of the night!  We will be making this for every get together from now on because it is so easy & turns out so great like you spent hours putting it together!

None
text:
LOVE this recipe.  I too do a whole package of cream cheese, but when I triple it I do 2 packages not three.  Also, I use frozen spinach, but I thaw it, squeeze out extra water, and then chop it.  I use the minced garlic from a jar, and always add in more than I need, and a little garlic powder too.  Also, I always go overboard on the cheese :) Maybe I'm just from Wisconsin, but I add always more cheese. I also have done it with roasted garlic alfredo sauce, and the four cheese alfredo sauce. It is famous amongst my family now, and it's what I bring to holidays!

text:
Served this at a party and it was a big hit.  Like others, I used a whole brick of cream cheese rather than half.  I used Classico Alfredo Sauce but would like to try Bertolli to see if that makes a difference in the taste.  The Classico seemed a bit mild so I added more parmesan cheese to the dip.  I mixed all of the ingredients together, rather than layering as the recipe says.  I made the dip the night before and kept in the fridge.  I cooked a little bit longer than 30 minutes since the dip was cold.  Served with pita chips and wheat thins.  This one is a keeper!

text:
I love this.  It was exactly the kind I was looking for: creamy, full of taste and not overwhelming.  The only thing I did different was that I did not use artichokes.  I might later.  Also,  I read that someone said you need to have the alfredo from the refrigerated section.  I didn't have that.  I had 2 jars of alfredo that I hadn't used yet so I grabbed one of those  and it worked great. I don't think it would be that big of a difference as long as you like the alfredo that you buy.  I served this with tortilla chips and it's definitely a great appettizer or even a great snack.  This one is going to be made again and again in this house, ty terrad!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dip turned out excellent.  We felt it was as good if not better than our favorite restaurant dip.  I did as some others have and used a full 8oz block of cream cheese.  I dialed down the artichokes to 4oz, used a 1tsp of minced garlic instead of cloves, 2 cups of Sargento 6 cheese italian blend shredded, and a full jar of Ragu roasted garlic parmesan sauce.  I just thawed the spinach and tossed everything into a 2qt crock pot.  ~45 min later it was ready.  It was perfect!  Thankyou so much!

text:
I have made this several times now, using a few variations.  Basically now I just throw in whatever ingredients I have that are similar to what is called for in this recipe - I always include the alfredo sauce, spinach, and mozzarella and parmesan cheeses. I add artichokes only if I have them, and I usually use sour cream instead of cream cheese, simply because I always have it on hand. Regardless of what I add/don't add - this is always delicious! It is literally fool-proof, and is amazing with tortilla chips.

I made this for my baby shower with about 40people--I doubled it to serve 25 and had plenty (it was away from the other food since I was keeping it warm on the stove)   EVERYONE raved about it though, they thought it was from tastfully simple! I used 3 packages of spinach, 1 can of artichokes, 2 1/2 packages of cream cheese and 1 jar of Alfredo, plenty of garlic, salt and pepper   Im so glad we have left overs its so good! I served it with sliced baguette and Hawaiian sweet bread.
